_exec_summary.SummaryText:
A.    Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies:



Woodford Express, LLC (Woodford Express) will operate a newly constructed natural gas processing plant (Grady Plant) located in Lindsay, Oklahoma.

It is Woodford Express' policy to adhere to all Federal and State rules and regulations.  The Grady Plant has established a commitment to worker and public safety as well as the environment. 

No regulated toxic chemicals (listed in 40 CFR ?68.130) will be handled at the Grady Plant.  The plant will handle flammable mixtures that meet the criteria for the National Fire Protection Association's (NFPA) 4 rating.  Safety precautions are in place when handling flammable mixtures to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to personal health and safety of personnel, contractors, the community and the environment.  

Grady Plant is designated as a Non-responding facility, which means that the local fire departments and other local emergency responders have primary responsibility for responding to accidental releases. The Grady Plant Emergency Action Plan (EAP) defines the steps the facility and each employee should take during an accidental release of a regulated substance.  The EAP includes both evacuation and protective action procedures for employees not directly involved in the response, and actions to be taken to ensure local emergency responders are informed of the event.  The EAP also includes procedures for notifying facility personnel, Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), and Chikasha Fire Departments.  



B.    The stationary source and regulated substances handled:



The Grady Plant will process natural gas received via pipeline and consists of two trains with a cryogenic processing capacity of 60 million standard cubic feet per day (MMSCFD). The gas is dehydrated and processed to remove heavy (liquid) hydrocarbons from the gas stream. The cryogenic unit is designed to liquefy natural gas liquids (NGL) from the dehydrated inlet

gas by removing heat from the gas. The cryogenic unit recovers NGL by cooling the gas stream and condensing components such as butane, ethane, pentane, propane and heavier.  The NGL and condensates are flammable mixtures that meet the criteria for the National Fire Protection Association's (NFPA) 4 rating and are handled in quantities that exceed EPA's threshold of 10,000 pounds.  



C.    The worst-case release scenarios and the alternative release scenarios

The scenarios were modeled assuming none of the protective barriers worked for the plant.



a.    Worst case scenario:

The off-site consequence analysis assumes that the vessel with the largest amount of flammable mixture (V-401 Slug Catcher) had a catastrophic failure. The flammable material is composed of a mixture that contains the following regulated substances: ethane, propane, butane, and pentane. It is assumed that the mixture is composed entirely of the chemical that would cause the worst damage (i.e. the predominant regulated flammable component of the mixture) in this case this substance is pentane.

The entire weight of the mixture is used to calculate the distance to the 1 psi overpressure endpoint. The scenario involved an uncontrolled release of 763,407 lb.  RMP Comp was used to predict a distance of 0.7 miles to the 1 psi endpoint, wind speed of 1.5 meters/second, stability class F with ambient air temperature (77 degrees F).   



b.    Alternative case scenarios:

Two alternative scenarios were evaluated.  One scenario was a 3 inch leak from the second largest amount of flammable mixture (Condensate Surge Tank V-403) resulting in vapor cloud fire. The second scenario was developed to identify a case closest to a public receptor.  This case evaluated a 4 inch leak from one of the Stabilized Condensate tanks (TK-452) resulting in a vapor cloud fire. 

The alternative scenarios were calculated using the chemical with the lowest lower flammability limit (LFL).  The LFL for butane, ethane and propane is

36 mg/L, and pentane has a LFL of 38 mg/L.  Thus ethane was the chemical used for the Surge Tank and butane for the Stabilize Condensate Tank in the analysis for the distance to the LFL limit.

RMP Comp was used to predict a distance of 0.1 miles to endpoint, wind speed of 3 m/s and a stability class D with ambient air temperature (77 degrees F).  



D.    General accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps:



The Grady Plant is a PSM-covered facility and, as such, it has a viable process safety program. Workers and their representatives are consulted and have access to information regarding all PSM elements. Complete and accurate information on the process technology, process equipment, hazardous characteristics and physical properties of all chemicals and intermediates for all covered processes is maintained. 

Process Hazards Analyses were conducted on the process to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled. Major hazards identified include fire, over-pressurization, overfilling, and equipment failure.  Process controls in place include relief valves, check valves, emergency and automatic shutdowns, grounding, interlocks and procedures and training. 

Trainings (initial and refresher) are conducted and includes on-the-job and classroom type training.  Written testing is used as means to verify understanding.  

Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) provide clear written instructions for conducting activities safely. SOPs address operating limits, safety and health considerations, and safety systems and their functions. SOPs are revised as necessary to reflect changes made to the process.  The written operating procedures are readily available to operators and for other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their job tasks.

A mechanical integrity program is in place that will will perform inspection and tests on equipment and correct any equipment deficiencies and apply

quality assurance measures. The facility has both predictive and preventative maintenance programs which include inspections, tests and routine maintenance activities that are performed by trained and competent employees and contractors.  Inspection and testing frequencies are prescribed by manufacturers and industry standards.  

A non-routine work authorization program ensures that appropriate measures are taken any time non-routine operations are performed on or near process areas that might initiate or promote a release.

Facility and process changes are managed through a management-of-change (MOC) program.  The MOC program outlines approval responsibilities and requires hazard evaluations prior to the implementation of any changes affecting a covered process.  Affected personnel and contractors are trained in the changes before the change is implemented.  

Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) conducted by appropriate employees, as spelled out in the facility's PSSR procedure. 

The facility has an active accident/incident prevention program.  Each incident and near miss associated with the process area is evaluated and, if it meets pre-defined criteria, a team-based investigation is performed.  The investigation's purpose is to identify root and contributing causes and to make recommendations to prevent future recurrence.  Recommendations from the Incident Investigation are tracked to closure.

Employees are active in all aspects of process safety, including safe work permitting, process hazard analyses, incident investigations, mechanical integrity and management of change.  

Additionally, contractors will be involved in many aspects of the programs.  Woodford Express will screen contractors based on safety performance before they are allowed entrance to the facility.  Employees responsible for projects involving contractors are encouraged to provide feedback to both management and the contractor on the contractor's overall safety performance.



E.    Five-year Ac

cident History 



The Grady Plant is a new facility in which operation has not yet begun; therefore, there are not incidents to be reported with the five-year accident history. 



F.    Emergency Response Program Information 



Grady Plant is designated as a Non-responding facility, which means that the local fire departments and other local emergency responders have primary responsibility for responding to accidental releases.

As part of the Emergency Response Program, the Grady Plant maintains a written Emergency Action Plan (EAP), which aims to protect employees, public health, and the environment (in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.38, 29CFR1910.119 and 40CFR68.90).  The EAP defines the steps the facility and each employee should take during an accidental release of a regulated substance.  Grady's employees will only handle incipient stage fires that can be handled with portable fire extinguishers and will not respond to larger releases or fires, but will conduct an Emergency Shutdown (ESD) of the facility and contact local emergency responders to respond.  The facility does not contain any regulated toxic substances, but only flammable substances above the threshold quantity (as listed in 40 CFR ?68.130).

Emergency contact information of Fire, Police and Sheriff Departments as well as Hospitals for major adjacent cities and local Emergency Planning Committee is included in the EAP.

The most recent review of the EAP was done in January, 2015.



G.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety 



The Grady Plant is committed to continuously improve the safe handling of the flammable mixtures in the process by implementing preventative maintenance programs, inspection programs, and employee training in the safe operation of the equipment; as well as periodic safety reviews and the incident investigation program.
